SENT.plain: ABSTRACT: BACKGROUND: In an ongoing clinical trial, the genetic and environmental risk assessment (GERA) blood test offers subjects information about personal colorectal cancer risk through measurement of two novel low-to-moderate risk factors
We sought to examine predictors of uptake of the GERA blood test among participants randomized to the Intervention arm

METHODS: Primary care patients aged 50 to 74 years eligible for colorectal cancer screening are randomized to receive a mailed stool blood test kit to complete at home (Control) or to the control condition plus an in-office blood test called GERA that includes assessment of red blood cell folate and DNA-testing for two MTHFR (methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase) single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) (Intervention)
For the present study, baseline survey data are examined in participants randomized to the Intervention
RESULTS: The first 351 intervention participants (161 African American/190 white) were identified
Predictors of GERA uptake included race (African American race, odds ratio (OR) 0.51 (0.29 to 0.87)), and being more knowledgeable about GERA and colorectal cancer screening (OR 1.09 (1.01 to 1.18))
Being married (OR 1.81 (1.09 to 3.00)) was also significant in the multivariable model
CONCLUSIONS: Participant uptake of GERA testing was high
GERA uptake varied, however, according to socio-demographic background and knowledge
